Some friends had not heard this Chinese parable. Sharing because it's always relevant:

A farmer owned a horse. One day, the horse ran away. 

The neighbors exclaimed, “Your horse ran away! What terrible luck!” 

The farmer replied, “Maybe. We will see.”

1105982376847568898.text:
If I offered you $1,000,000,000 would you:

- Permanently destroy your mental health?
- Give up one of your senses?
- Agree to never see your loved ones again?
- Give up laughter?
- Give up your memories?

Money is important but know its place,

You're already worth billions.

1103297959373008896.text: I’ve been thinking a lot about the importance of memos for remote orgs, and our necessity to rely on them more heavily. The key insight is that they aren’t just for rich info sharing (good), but because they force us to explicitly articulate the ideas stuck in our heads (great!)

1100058665774592001.text:
In my clinical experience, most people struggle because their main motivations in life are to:

1) Feel good (addiction)
2) Avoid pain (avoidance)
3) Be right (ego)

Rather, I help people:
1) Be present (mindfulness) 
2) Open up (willingness)
3) Do what matters (be effective)

Your coffee is too hot. Your brain runs on autopilot. You’ve forgotten to stop and remember you’re alive.

Why does Ethereum matter?

1) A globally accessible financial system
2) An low risk platform for entrepreneurs to build (compared to building off a company's API)
3) Micro-democracies; code values into money (I.e. 5% of block rewards to open source)  

Agree? What else?

What is your single most important daily habit? 

Bonus points for nonobvious habits (i.e not related to sleep or exercise).

1078029159291670532.text:

An incremental example of why open beats closed in the long run.

Good read: https://opentextbc.ca/principlesofeconomics/chapter/13-3-public-goods/ …pic.twitter.com/RLNOovnp4X

1076136541314056193.text:

1072309832848433152.text:
"First you will reach the Sirens, who bewitch
all passersby. If anyone goes near them
in ignorance, and listens to their voices,
that man will never travel to his home,
and never make his wife and children happy
to have him back with them again." 

What are your Sirens? #Odyssey

1071497877900414976.text:
"Why I Write" by George Orwell. He cites ego, history, beauty, and politics.

"It is also true that one can write nothing readable unless one constantly struggles to efface one’s own personality." 

http://srjcstaff.santarosa.edu/~mheydon/whywriteD.pdf …

1070118361445453824.text: "You must prize vulnerability. Radical vulnerability. Follow your work into its darkest corners and strangest manifestations, revealing things about yourself that you don't want to reveal until your work requires you to do so, and never failing in only mediocre or generic ways."

1069762036895309824.text:

1055434016495726592.text:
There were even more links and resources — feel free to DM me for the list if interested! I’ll share the YouTube version of the discussion below when it’s available. 

Huge thanks to @thegrifft, @Givethio and everyone else for a wonderful discussion environment.

1055434014885138433.text:
Being Web 3 Summit, we heard of creative approaches for future OSS. @lftherios explained @oscoin in more detail, a project we’re excited to collaborate alongside at @GetGitcoin.

One of the key ideas: Using inflation funding to help open source projects govern their commons.

1055434013257752576.text: In the book, Elinor speaks of 8 key principles necessary for managing commons — whether over-exploited fisheries, pastures, space, or open source software.https://makewealthhistory.org/2018/01/15/elinor-ostroms-8-rules-for-managing-the-commons/ …

1055434011500339201.text:
From here, someone from the crowd pulled out ‘Governing The Commons’, a book by Elinor Ostrom. She won the Nobel in 2009 for debunking the (then) popular opinion that ‘The Tragedy Of The Commons’ was inevitable. 

https://www.amazon.com/Governing-Commons-Evolution-Institutions-Collective/dp/1107569788/ref=dp_ob_title_bk …

1055434010023903232.text:
We also discussed Sustain, a fantastic open source conference (meeting today in London)! Say hi to @owocki and @coderberry if you are there  

Their report is a great resource for OSS - be on the lookout for a 2018 version soon!

https://sustainoss.org/assets/pdf/SustainOSS-west-2017-report.pdf …

1055434008459440130.text: While sharing @nadia resources, sharing Lemonade Stand is a no brainer. This explores different ways to fund open source — for contributors, maintainers, and more.https://github.com/nayafia/lemonade-stand …

1055434006999769088.text: This started with ‘Rebuilding The Cathedral’, a 2017 talk about maintainer overload by @nayafia. The talk is great - the slides speak for themselves.https://www.slideshare.net/NadiaEghbal/rebuilding-the-cathedral …

1055434005334712320.text: We then got a bit into the struggles and realities of present day open source. @richlitt from http://Maintainer.io  shared some great resources and thoughts to inform this part of the conversation.https://maintainer.io/

1055434003610828800.text: Then, @notscottmoore helped us understand the differences between the GPL and MIT licensees, which are succinctly explained below. TL;DR — use MIT if you don’t mind if people use it for anything (including closed source), GPL otherwise.https://choosealicense.com/

1055434001954062336.text: We reviewed ‘The Cathedral and The Bazaar’, a seminal piece explaining the benefits of developing in an open source fashion.https://medium.com/gitcoin/the-cathedral-and-the-bazaar-5b97349fd53b …

1055434000293072896.text:
We begun with a history of open source and the difference between free software and open software. 

This begins Richard Stallman, and continues with Linus Torvalds and Eric Raymond, among many others.https://medium.com/gitcoin/a-brief-history-of-open-source-3928cb451767 …

1055433998435078145.text:
Yesterday we hosted a great discussion at @Web3Summit regarding the past, present, and future of open source. 

Many links were shared and I thought it’d be worth sharing a curated list. Let's go!

1032744663382413313.text:
The idea is simple. 

As a developer, find an Github issue you'd like to work and tell us how much funding you'd need to do so.

As a maintainer, send us any Github issues you'd like help on from the crowd. We'll bounty the best issues.https://gitcoin.co/requests/

1032744661721538560.text:
Very excited to announce the launch of @GetGitcoin Requests today! 

This is a step forward in our vision to build Gitcoin as a platform that maximizes freedom for developers - one of the core tenants of open source.https://medium.com/@vivek.m.singh/gitcoin-requests-baf522d4645d …

1024666728347906048.text:

@cryptowanderer has helped broaden my perspective. Head down the rabbit hole yourself!https://our.status.im/the-grand-design-such-as-it-is/ …

1024666722018750466.text:
I’m unsure on Andy's musings on DAO’s and the ‘perfect language’ because the representation problem still exists. 

We're two difficult steps away from accurately conveying our intentions with code, speech, or writing. DAO's will struggle unless we solve representation. Right?pic.twitter.com/UuH9gwFsPd

1024666720710139905.text:
Andy's writing takes "code as speech" from @naval even further. 

He previously explored why binary (code-based) writing could approach 'the perfect language'. With this premise, he adds Bitcoin in 2009 as a language-event.http://andytudhope.africa/language-in-the-ether/ …

1024666718688485376.text: Finally, “language-events” change how we interact with language. Andy cites writing, which “gave us the ability to externalize consciousness, and therefore manipulate it in previously unimaginable ways.”

1024666715890823168.text:
A quality of language is decentralization. No one controls language.

“Languages are logically decentralized; the English spoken between Alice and Bob and the English spoken between Charlie and David do not need to agree at all." - @VitalikButerinhttps://medium.com/@VitalikButerin/the-meaning-of-decentralization-a0c92b76a274 …

1024666714586447883.text:
This brings us to language, a great tool with a fatal flaw.

"Language is always only a representation of a representation of the thing itself. We are always, at best, two steps removed from what we talk about. This abstraction is the root of both language's power and failure."

1024666713302945794.text:
Ubuntu doesn’t mean you can’t achieve individuality. 

It “implies both the possibility of individuation, of human-being, and the impossibility of achieving that without also acknowledging that one's individuality rests upon relationship with others.”

1024666711675559936.text:
I recently read posts from @cryptowanderer on the meta-relationship between language and cryptocurrencies. Chalk full of intriguing ideas. 

It starts before language, with *ubuntu*: “A human being is only a human being through other human beings.”https://our.status.im/the-grand-design-such-as-it-is/ …

986389334503936002.text:
Obviously, don't quote anybody on the above. My own misinterpretations are possible. One of my favorite conversations of the month, so figured I’d share.

/FIN.

986389333254066178.text: 2/ @naval pointed out notable exceptions include outright geniuses like Einstein, who *thought* of General Relativity even though all signs on earth pointed to a different formula. This genius is the exception, applied science → theory is the rule.

986389331484053505.text: 1/ In blockchain world,  this started with Satoshi and has continued with Vitalik. They posited what a functioning prototype would need, built it, and now sciences, like 'cryptoeconomics', are being created. Learn more below https://twitter.com/karl_dot_tech/status/984908408477372418 …

986389330716495872.text: Thought #5: In most cases, applied research leads to experimentation, which then creates new theories.

986389329697177600.text: 3/ At a different point in conversation, we revisited the "future of work". Blockchain world is one of the first industries bring @naval's predictions of highly mobile, distributed teams to life. This will likely continue.

986389328728379393.text: 2/ Thus, a re-imagination of education (and the ability for humans to educate post adolescence) is key. Obviously, easier said than done. But, this stands against many theories on "the future of work" trending to 'no work'.

986389327566528515.text: 1/ A thought experiment: if every human in the world was meaningfully educated, would "lack of work" seem likely? Not particularly.

986389326681567233.text: Thought #4: Seeing "no work in the future" is largely unimaginative. There will always be something to do.

986389325733662720.text: Thought #3: “Business is applied art.” - @naval. Usually not appreciated as such because it’s also economically motivated, it's an expression of creativity and human ingenuity.

986389324584407040.text: 3/ @VitalikButerin then brought up a book called Radical Markets, where the author posits a theoretical approach to making a jubilee possible. Still on pre-sale.. I need his connects.https://www.amazon.com/Radical-Markets-Uprooting-Capitalism-Democracy-ebook/dp/B0773X7RKB/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1524007469&sr=8-1&keywords=radical+markets …

986389323519070208.text:
2/ From Debt: The First 5000 Years, “All revolutionary movements had a single program: ‘Cancel the debts and redistribute the land.’”   

https://www.amazon.com/Debt-Updated-Expanded-First-Years-ebook/dp/B00Q1HZMCW/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1524007961&sr=8-1&keywords=debt+the+first+5000+years …

986389322512388097.text: 1/ This would be akin to a digital "land redistribution" the likes of which have never been seen (or possible) before blockchains.

986389321178591232.text: Thought #2: A blockchain based "jubilee", where the ledger was completely cleared and restarted every x (50, 100) years.

986389319895212037.text: 4/ @karl_dot_tech then brought up Circles, a fascinating model on kicking this off from a bottom-up approach as opposed to top-down, via airdrop.https://joincircles.net

986389318628503552.text: 3/ Why would this matter? Could serve as the backdrop for your identity (like a digital passport / citizenship), UBI, and protect against many hard digital problems.

986389317219209217.text: 2/ This token might distribute 75% now, 25% later and have an inflation rate tied to population growth. The token supply grows as population grows, and a token is distributed at birth (and another at a milestone like 18, maybe).

986389315969220609.text: 1/ The essential idea here is a blockchain based protocol that issues a token (or few tokens) to someone simply for existing.

986389314257989632.text: Thought #1: “Proof of Human” is one exciting blockchain project still yet to be created.

986389313016430592.text: I was lucky to have a spontaneous and wide ranging chat with @Naval and other blockchain leaders recently. Here are some of the most interesting things said.

908780579881136129.text: "Where you stand is determined by where you sit."
